Devious Myra Hindley told police that she “can’t stand blood” and was never present when the five Moors Murders victims died. 
The warped killer’s bid to distance herself from the horror came in interviews 20 years after the murders . 
But Hindley also told Det Chief Supt Peter Topping in 1987 she was “as guilty” as accomplice Ian Brady as she helped lure the children who died. 
The revelations come in 700 pages of interviews uncovered by Moors Murders expert Darren Rae. 
Hindley was quizzed as police mounted a new bid to find the bodies of three victims of the 1960s killings. Read More Myra Hindley claimed the hate blood (Photo: BBC) Ian Brady under arrest (Photo: Manchester Evening News Archive) 
She told Topping: “I wouldn’t say I willingly co-operated with Ian Brady but I complied with his wishes, ­everything he wanted to do. 
“I am guilty of abduction, not having committed a physical murder myself, of being tantamount to murder for which I feel as guilty as he is. 
“I was virtually a murderess, how many women went around abducting children to take them to their deaths?” 
Last week we revealed how Hindley claimed that lover Brady had “become her God”. A body of one of the murderous pair's victims is taken off the moors Darren Rae at the shrine to Keith Bennett (Photo: John Gladwin/Sunday Mirror) 
Darren also said he had found shells matching a gun owned by Brady on Saddleworth Moor, Gtr Manchester. 
He is convinced Brady shot 12-year-old Keith Bennett there. 
The interviews with Topping were conducted at Cookham Wood jail in Kent. Hindley died in 2002, aged 60. 
She and Brady were jailed for life in 1966 over the murders of Lesley Ann Downey, John Kilbride and Edward Evans. Darren on the moors (Photo: John Gladwin/Sunday Mirror) 
In 1985 Brady – still held at Ashworth Hospital, Merseyside – confessed to murdering Pauline Reade and Keith Bennett, 12. 
Darren is writing a book – Finding Keith? The Definitive Investigation into the Moors Murders – which fully ­documents his new evidence. Keith Bennett, 12 12 year old Keith Bennett (Photo: PA) 
Young Keith Bennett was lured on to the Moors “like a lamb to the slaughter”, Hindley told police. 
The 12-year-old’s body has never been found after she and Brady kidnapped him in June 1964. 
Hindley told how Brady was hiding in the back of their van as they went out looking for a victim. 
They spotted Keith and Brady tapped Hindley. “I knew he would,” she told police. Pauline Reade was 16 when she was killed (Photo: PA) Joan Reade mother of Moors Murder victim Pauline Reade 
She asked Keith if he would help carry boxes from a wine shop. 
She told police chief Topping: “The awful thing is about all these children they never queried anything, probably because of me being a woman that they didn’t have any fear or anything.” 
At Saddleworth Moor Keith got out of the van and “just went like a little lamb to the slaughter”, she said. Victim John Kilbride, 12 (Photo: PA) 
Hindley stood on lookout for 40 minutes while Brady strangled Keith and buried him “a long, long walk” from the road. 
She told of a letter from Keith’s mum Winnie Johnson. Hindley said: “I can’t put into words how I feel that Keith Bennett’s body can’t be found.” 
Winnie died in 2012. Lesley Ann Downey, 10 Lesley-Ann Downey, 10 (Photo: PA) 
Terrified Lesley Ann Downey was taped pleading for her mum as she was abused and tortured. 
The 10-year-old was snatched from a fairground in December 1964 after Brady said he wanted to “do blue photographs”. 
Hindley said: “He said we would bring whoever it was back to the house to do blue photographs which he said he would sell. 
"These children who we killed, they could have been anybody, if it hadn’t been them it would have been someone else.” 
Of Lesley Ann, Hindley added: “She was crying and screaming and I know I should have tried to protect the child to comfort her. 
"I didn’t, I was cruel and I was brusque and I told her to shut up because I was frightened that people would hear and I panicked. It was just like a nightmare. 
“She was terrified out of her life, frightened to death, she was hysterical. 
“I don’t have no defence.” 
Hindley claimed she was running a bath for Lesley Ann when Brady strangled the youngster. Edward Evans, 17 Edward Evans, 17-year-old murder victim of Ian Brady and Myra Hindley (Photo: PA) 
Hindley tried to implicate her brother-in-law over the axe murder of final victim Edward Evans. 
In the interviews she claimed David Smith was involved in killing Edward, 17, who Brady had lured back to his house in October 1965. 
Hindley told Topping there was a fight between Brady and Evans. 
She said: “I heard a sound like a chair crashing across the floor, scraping across the floor. 
"I looked through the hatch and saw Ian and Edward Evans struggling with each other. I ran into the hallway and I shouted ‘Dave, help him’.” 
She claimed Smith ran to the living room, adding: “All hell let loose... there was screaming. When it stopped everywhere was just one complete pool of blood. 
“I couldn’t go in because I cannot stand blood and I can’t bear it. I ran into the kitchen and was horribly sick.” 
After cleaning up the mess she told police how they sat drinking tea while planning how to dispose of the body. 
In reality, Smith was not involved in the murder. He alerted police – leading to the capture of Brady and Hindley. Anyone with information can email Darren at contact@impsar.org Like us on Facebook
